messageBody:
David Saff wrote:
> Michael Herrmann wrote:
>
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <saff@m...> wrote:
> > > There's an interesting, whimsical point in favor of @Before that I'll
> > > bring up in a future post.
> >
> > Now you've made me curious :) please do tell us.
>
> Sorry--it was at the end of my first post about behavior-driven
> development. Since some people see benefit in thinking about frameworks
> similar to JUnit in terms of behavior, and not testing, perhaps there is
> a benefit in cognitive flexibility to leaving the annotation @Before
> instead of @BeforeTest. @BeforeTest is somewhat "hardcoding the
> metaphor". However, since I'm still contrigued about behavior-driven
> development, this is just a whimsical thought.

I liked @Before and @BeforeClass. I'm not sure why I suggested
@BeforeTest and @BeforeSuite. It's that dinosaur thing again.

> But it's really just using summaryString as a testing utility. I'd be
> tempted to write this instead, which feels clearer:
>
> assertThat(states, summarizeTo("GREEN 0.0 GREEN 0.5 RED 1.0"))

The problem with this is that you lose the context of the "states"
object in the method "summarizeTo". Generalizing this looks bad, as it
resorts to the kind of reflection you showed next:

> Constraint summarizeTo(String summary) {
> return applyTo(eq(summary), callMethod("summaryString"));
> }

callMethod on which object? Bang, you're dead. :)

I've thought about the difference between:

assertEquals(expected, states.summary());

and

assertTrue(states.summaryEquals(expected));

They're the same, except that the summary() method has a higher chance
of being useful in contexts other than testing, whereas summaryEquals()
stands no such chance. As a result, I choose the former.

So...

assertThat(states.summary(), eq(new Summary(0, 0.5, 1));

would be my choice.
